Name: The Passive Solar Energy Book: A Complete Guide to Passive Solar Home, Greenhouse and Building Design

ReviewList.Text: From a number of books I have been reading on passive energy topics, Mazria's small book is the most concrete, understandable and organized. I designed my home using the book and the forecasted energy compsumption  matched the calculations!

A seminal reference on the fundamentals of solar design.  Easily used, yet thorough and quantitative.  Should be required reading for everyone in the architecture & building design fields.  Sunfall info given here is relevant to every structure ever designed -- and if you actually use it, the info *will* improve your design!!

When I designed our first house this book was invaluable.  We are now designing our second home and looked to see if there is an update.  Unfortunately it has not been revised but then little has changed with the  sun and mass and the book will once again be a valued resource.

As everyone else has indicated, this is by far the best passive solar design book in our library.  It contains all the information necessary to properly design a solar passive house.  The only negative is that it is 1979 Copyright, out of print, and may therefore be hard to acquire.  The best current book that we have is by Daniel D. Chiras, "The Solar House".  James Kachadorian's "The Passive Solar House" is also an excellent current book in terms of the excellent engineering information provided although some of the slab construction recommendations may be somewhat dated and not in line with current best practice.  The worst book we have encountered was Debra Coleman's "Sun Inspired House".  This book is merely an advertisement of the plans she sells and we would definitely advise applying due diligence if considering to do business with her.  For those interested in doing passive solar design, we added some calculators to our website that you can find by Googling Borst Engineering & Construction LLC.

One of my favorite books on passive solar...very complete,useful information, temperature performance and rules of thumb on relation of thermal mass and glass area etc.....and thanks god the book is written in a down to earth style and not overloaded with useless equations such as in Kreidler's books on active solar systems. that book is a must have....and bearing in mind that you get that marvel of a book used for less than 10c it should be punished not having a copy!!

If you are designing a house this is a must for the basics in Passive Solar. No panels, no wires, no permits - just free warmth AND cooling.  I used this to design my home in SW Colorado in 1992 and its fantastic. I got this one for my nephew to design his new home.

Concepts presented very clearly with excellent illustrations, the full run-down on various passive solar strategies, comprehensive but doesn't feel overly technical, easy to understand why this stands as a classic on passive solar design.

Great book for individuals who want to understand how to harness natural energy to their own benefit as well as benefitting the global economy by saving on energy consumption. The diagrams and drawings are very intuitive.
Extremely well crafted in the understanding of living w/ and plying the effects of solar energy principles.
This is the design authority for energy crisis 1.0 passive solar design.  Very appropriate today.
He's the most knowledgeable person on the subject. EVERYONE should be reading this
WOW!!!! Old book but still very relevant, Sun did not move much in 40 years :)
Book had its spine broken but as a beginner book for a teenager wanting to learn about solar power it was acceptable.
This book is outdated. All black k and white photos. Information is poorly explained. This book was published undercover 30 years ago.
